RT @SMMTTHREAD 🚗🚢🌍
SMMT sets out 10 recommendations to help keep auto at the heart of the UK’s future trade strategy

Trade recommendation no1

As the UK’s largest exporter of industrial goods, any
UK trade policy needs to have the auto industry
at its centre

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/JdqnEzIBsE

Trade recommendation no. 10

Immediate support for automotive businesses to
restart UK manufacturing, incentivise consumer demand
and aid UK economic recovery is a necessary intervention
by the government. 

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/UcA5kWbDuU

Trade recommendation no. 9

UK trade ambitions must sensibly align with the mission
statements set out by the joint government-industry
@AutoCouncilUK
 as well as reflect the Grand Challenges
detailed in government’s Industrial Strategy. 

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/wsQz8pJAzG

Trade recommendation no. 8

UK automotive businesses should identify and map
vulnerabilities in their existing business model. Innovative
distribution and sales channels and the diversification of
customers and export markets could mitigate future risks

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/K1KxV4YrG1

Trade recommendation no. 7

Building on close collaboration with major trading
partners, the government should guarantee efficient trade facilitation measures which avoid costly delays at the border. 

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/kj9rWj9qmf

Trade recommendation no. 6

Government and industry should explore the markets
where the potential for meaningful access improvements
for UK exporters may be the greatest. 

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/wtM9vzMBNC

Trade recommendation no. 5

Government should encourage the growth of trade by
examining and removing existing market access barriers
which negatively affect trade between the UK and its key
trading partners. 

https://t.co/S6rf51LnCT https://t.co/aud235D2tp

Trade recommendation no. 4

As a major exporting market, future UK trade strategies
must receive the buy-in of UK automotive businesses. 

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/Ajnz8Pa8j1

Trade recommendation no. 3

Government should explore all avenues to protect
Automotive and those sectors relevant to the supply chain from international trade disputes.  

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/vaADWgj21r

Trade recommendation no. 2

The conclusion of an ambitious free trade agreement
with the EU is the essential pre-condition to ensure
the long-term viability of the sector and boost the UK’s
attractiveness as a production centre of new models. 

https://t.co/S6rf522Z1t https://t.co/2rxsxR7G1B

RT @SMMTTHREAD: SMMT sets out 10 recommendations to help keep auto at the heart of the UK’s future trade strategy

Trade recommendation no. 1

As the UK’s largest exporter of industrial goods, any
UK trade policy needs to have the auto industry
at its centre

https://t.co/3qmzyUWyMG https://t.co/aSHxp5O0mB

Trade recommendation no. 10

Immediate support for automotive businesses to
restart UK manufacturing, incentivise consumer demand
and aid UK economic recovery is a necessary intervention
by the government. 

https://t.co/3qmzyUWyMG https://t.co/fFrtIAZxWv

Trade recommendation no. 9

UK trade ambitions must sensibly align with the mission
statements set out by the joint government-industry
@AutoCouncilUK as well as reflect the Grand Challenges
detailed in government’s Industrial Strategy. 

https://t.co/3qmzyUWyMG https://t.co/CZ6CSd5KH5

Trade recommendation no. 8

UK automotive businesses should identify and map
vulnerabilities in their existing business model. Innovative
distribution and sales channels and the diversification of
customers and export markets could mitigate future risks

https://t.co/3qmzyUWyMG https://t.co/e8GW7E3bKh

Trade recommendation no. 7

Building on close collaboration with major trading
partners, the government should guarantee efficient trade facilitation measures which avoid costly delays at the border. 

https://t.co/3qmzyUWyMG https://t.co/Vva980MLRr

Trade recommendation no. 6

Government and industry should explore the markets
where the potential for meaningful access improvements
for UK exporters may be the greatest. 

https://t.co/3qmzyUWyMG https://t.co/E2IeEBzihH

Trade recommendation no. 5

Government should encourage the growth of trade by
examining and removing existing market access barriers
which negatively affect trade between the UK and its key
trading partners.

Peter Stephens: "Most EVs are bought on a finance package, so it’s about the monthly cost, not the ticket price. With the lower running costs and reduced taxation, they’re very competitive and we find that once people switch to electric, they don’t switch back"
Frank Samolis: "Negotiations on a US-UK FTA is ongoing, and progress is being made. Regulatory coherence would be much more uniform between the two nations"
Glenn Schmidt: "There’s a lot of focus on public charging infrastructure but 80% of charging is done at home or work, so we need to look at that if we want to increase accessibility"

Peter Stephens: "Manufacturers need to bring forward the right products, national governments need to give the right clear policy framework, and local authorities need to ensure the charging infrastructure is available. We all need to work together"
Sascha Kaehne: Gas-fuelled trucks make up about 3% of registrations overall, but for us, it’s around 15% of our sales
Iana Dreyer: "There is political will to get to a UK-EU FTA. We are moving to a very different type of relationship, far away from a single market"
Peter Stephens: "Lockdown has shown an opportunity for real growth for 100% electric vehicles. Electric vans are a great option for last-mile delivery"
Ian Plummer: "Although our research shows 77% of buyers are considering an electric vehicle, we’re still a long way off being able to claim that electric is the new normal"
Glenn Schmidt: "The ‘new normal’ is the ‘power of choice’ – be it electric, plug-in hybrid or efficient conventional engines"
Sascha Kaehne: "hydrogen will dominate in long-haul truck distribution, and in the meantime, natural gas will be the transition technology for the next 10-15 years"
Frank Samolis: "It has been an extraordinary year and trade patterns have changed drastically"
Iana Dreyer: "We are seeing the rise of economic nationalism and protectionist tariffs"
Julian Braithwaite CMG: "The UK has taken back its independent seat at the WTO and is in a good position"
